name: Restoration of the Society of Jesus
summary: Pope Pius VII restored the Society of Jesus (Jesuits) through the bull 'Sollicitudo omnium ecclesiarum' in 1814, ending the suppression that had been in effect since 1773. The restoration came during a period when the Church needed the Jesuits' educational and missionary work. The order quickly regained its influence and became one of the largest and most active religious orders in the Church.

name: Dogma of the Immaculate Conception
summary: Pope Pius IX defined the dogma of the Immaculate Conception in the apostolic constitution 'Ineffabilis Deus' on December 8, 1854. The dogma teaches that the Blessed Virgin Mary was preserved from original sin from the moment of her conception. This was the first time a pope exercised papal infallibility in defining a dogma, though the doctrine itself had been widely held for centuries.

name: Apparitions of Our Lady of Lourdes
summary: Between February 11 and July 16, 1858, the Blessed Virgin Mary appeared 18 times to 14-year-old Bernadette Soubirous in a grotto near Lourdes, France. The apparition identified herself as 'the Immaculate Conception' and revealed a spring with healing properties. Lourdes became one of the most important Marian pilgrimage sites in the world, with millions of pilgrims visiting annually and many documented healings.

name: First Vatican Council
summary: The First Vatican Council was convoked by Pope Pius IX and met from 1869 to 1870. It was the 20th ecumenical council of the Catholic Church. The council defined the dogma of papal infallibility and the primacy of papal jurisdiction. The council was interrupted by the Franco-Prussian War and the capture of Rome, and was never formally closed, though it effectively ended with the suspension of sessions.

name: Dogma of Papal Infallibility
summary: The First Vatican Council defined the dogma of papal infallibility in the constitution 'Pastor Aeternus' on July 18, 1870. The dogma states that when the pope speaks ex cathedra (from the chair of Peter) on matters of faith and morals, he is preserved from error by the Holy Spirit. This was a controversial definition that led to the formation of the Old Catholic Church by those who rejected it.

name: Capture of Rome and End of Papal States
summary: On September 20, 1870, Italian troops breached the walls of Rome and captured the city, ending the temporal power of the papacy and the Papal States that had existed for over a thousand years. Pope Pius IX declared himself a 'prisoner in the Vatican' and refused to recognize the Italian state. This situation, known as the Roman Question, would last until the Lateran Treaty of 1929.

name: Rerum Novarum
summary: Pope Leo XIII issued the encyclical 'Rerum Novarum' on May 15, 1891, addressing the condition of the working classes. It was the first major Catholic social encyclical and established the Church's position on labor rights, private property, the role of the state, and the rights and duties of workers and employers. It laid the foundation for modern Catholic social teaching and influenced labor movements worldwide.

name: Kulturkampf
summary: The Kulturkampf (culture struggle) was a conflict between the German government under Chancellor Otto von Bismarck and the Catholic Church from 1871 to 1878. The government passed laws restricting Catholic influence, expelling Jesuits, controlling education, and requiring state approval for clerical appointments. The conflict ended with a compromise, but it demonstrated the tensions between the Church and modern nation-states.
